newsitem.title: UK: Red Cross denies Diana about-turn on Bosnia trip.
newsitem.headline: Red Cross denies Diana about-turn on Bosnia trip.

text.p: The British Red Cross on Tuesday denied reports from Sarajevo that Princess Diana had pulled out of a planned trip to Bosnia because she might have ended up meeting the wife of wanted war criminal Radovan Karadzic.

A spokeswoman for the Red Cross said Bosnia was one of a number of countries Diana had considered visiting as part of her campaign with the Red Cross against the use of landmines but that a visit had not been firmly planned.
However, a Western official in Sarajevo said the princess had cancelled a planned visit there "due to political sensitivities".
"There was a concern she would meet Mrs Karadzic, wife of the indicted war criminal, and therefore the visit is not taking place at all," the official told Reuters.
"When Mrs Karadzic is no longer president of local Red Cross in Bosnian Serb territory, then the visit will be renegotiated," the official, who asked not to be named, said.
Ljiljana Karadzic is the head of the Serb Republic of Bosnia's Red Cross, an organisation not officially recognised by the International Federation of the Red Cross.
Her husband is wanted by the United Nations to face genocide charges dating from the Bosnian war.

The princess would have had reason to visit Bosnia in the coming months because the Red Cross is about to launch a "Mines Awareness Programme" there and her spokeswoman said she was keen to make further visits in the anti-landmine campaign.
But the Red Cross spokeswoman said similar programmes in other countries such as Cambodia might prove more interesting for the princess and provide better publicity for the campaign.

Diana -- former wife of heir to the throne Prince Charles -- made a high profile visit to Angola earlier this year to highlight the Red Cross campaign against landmines and to publicise the fact that it was an issue she felt strongly about.
If she has been obliged to cancel a trip to Bosnia, it will be the second time she has been forced into diplomatic backtracking in her mission to get landmines banned.

Last month, she cancelled a visit to the British parliament to hear a discussion about landmines after opposition Conservative members of parliament objected that, as a royal, she had no right to get involved in politics.
In the same week, the princess apologised after taking her under-age son to see a film sympathetic to the outlawed Irish Republican Army (IRA).
